awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Utilizing Reinforcement Learning to Optimize Ocean Wave Energy Capture
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project seeks to facilitate the blue economy’s continued transition to a big-data paradigm. Currently, there is no cost-effective power solution for off-grid, small-scale, energy capture applications at sea. The project deliverables may benefit the commercial ocean sector as well as the Federal government and local municipalities by enabling cheaper and more reliable power at sea. This enabling technology may contribute to the ability for planners and decision-makers to anticipate and adapt to changing marine conditions, which will ultimately reduce costs and increase reliability for taxpayers. Additionally, to achieve its commercial objectives, the participating small business is committed to sustainability in its growth plan and aims to reduce carbon emission by working with local vendors and locally-sourced, recyclable materials. The small business will also continue its existing partnerships with local technical training/trade schools and workforce development programs to mentor underserved students and create jobs.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project seeks to leverage advanced artificial intelligence for optimizing power output. The project seeks to demonstrate the application of advanced machine learning techniques to improve the efficiency and energy capture, and reduce the intermittency, of renewable ocean-based power generation. The project enables adaptability by using an advanced control model methodology which adjusts the device hardware based on ambient environmental conditions for optimized performance. Due to the deployment environment, this project will capture training data under a laboratory setting, train the control model offline, and apply it in the field by leveraging edge computing.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes Report

NSF SBIR Phase I Project: Utilizing Reinforcement Learning to Optimize Ocean Wave Energy Capture

Alexander J. Orona (P.I.) and B. Jack Pan, Ph.D.

Ocean Motion Technologies, Inc.

 

Executive Summary

Ocean Motion Technologies (OMT) successfully completed the NSF SBIR Phase I project, focusing on enhancing wave energy capture through the Adaptive Point Attenuator enhanced with advanced artificial intelligence control system (APA-AI). This technology represents a significant advancement in harvesting energy from ocean waves, improving efficiency by over 27% compared to baseline models​.

Project Background

The APA-AI is a groundbreaking wave energy converter, integrating advanced AI for adaptability in diverse marine environments. It's designed for installation on commercial oceanographic data buoys, addressing the challenge of energy capture volatility due to the ocean's dynamic nature. Traditional models, optimized for specific wave conditions, often underperform when wave characteristics change. The APA-AI, through its AI-driven control model, adapts in real-time to varying wave heights, wavelengths, frequencies, and amplitudes, thereby maximizing energy capture​.

Commercialization Prospects

Phase I results indicate a 50% increase in the device's value due to enhanced power generation capabilities, justifying a unit price of $15,000. This technology caters to two key market segments: new buoy purchases and existing buoy operations. The AI system significantly benefits users by supporting more robust and frequent data transmission and analysis capabilities, essential for diverse applications ranging from scientific research to fisheries management​.

Project Objectives and Achievements

● Data Collection System: Developed a low-energy system for collecting data on approaching waves, essential for training the AI model.

● Training Dataset Assembly: Compiled a comprehensive dataset, combining real-world data and synthetic simulations, to model various wave conditions and inform the AI system's training.

● AI Model Development: Created and validated a control model to optimize device settings based on the ambient wave environment, which utilizes advanced machine learning techniques and hyperparameter searches to train​.

 Research and Results Summary

A substantial portion of the project was dedicated to developing a standardized training procedure for the AI control model. This model, trained using both real-world and synthetic data, is capable of dynamically adjusting the APA's settings, including arm configurations and heave stiffness, for optimal energy capture. The APA-AI's design, featuring low-energy sensors, emphasizes simplicity and efficiency, crucial for operations in remote or harsh marine settings​.

Innovative Contributions and Future Directions

The APA-AI has demonstrated substantial commercial and environmental adaptability. Its ability to adjust to varying wave conditions in real-time significantly enhances performance and addresses intermittency issues common in sustainable energy sources. The methodologies and software developed are not limited to the APA but are applicable to a wide range of sustainable energy devices requiring environmental adaptability​.

 

The successful completion of the NSF SBIR Phase I project by OMT sets a strong foundation for further development and commercialization of the APA-AI, paving the way for significant advancements in renewable ocean wave energy conversion. The team looks forward to Phase II, focusing on broader applications and further enhancements of this transformative technology.


Last Modified: 01/26/2024
Modified by: Alexander J Orona
